channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Chicago responds to President Trump's threats of troop deployment
item.description: WBEZ's Adriana Cardona Maguigad reports on reaction in Chicago as Trump renews threats to send in National Guard troops and increase ICE enforcement.

item.title: Massachusetts makes progress on regional health care coalition
item.description: The Boston Globe's Jason Laughlin explains how Massachusetts and other states are forming independent healthcare coalitions to fill in the gap on healthcare policy left by sweeping federal changes.

item.title: Who makes the rules at immigration court? Reporting on chaotic scenes in courthouse halls
item.description: NPR's Ximena Bustillo talks to Scott Detrow about what reporting on the immigration court has been like recently, and describes the chaotic courthouse hallways she's been navigating.

item.title: A week in Beijing shows Putin is keeping China very close
item.description: Russian president Vladimir Putin spent the week in China, attending a summit and very publicly aligning himself with Xi Jinping. Alexander Gabuev, director of the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center, explains why this matters to the US and Ukraine.

item.title: A musical about Luigi Mangione sells out theatres - and raises eyebrows
item.description: The UnitedHealthcare CEO's alleged killer was in the same Brooklyn jail as Diddy and Sam Bankman-Fried. A satirical comedy about their jailhouse vibe is selling out theaters and raising eyebrows.

item.title: They called him 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church canonizes the first millenial saint
item.description: The Catholic Church is about to canonize its first saint of the millennial generation.

item.title: Coffee-fueled dance parties give Seattle's Latino community a place to connect
item.description: Daytime booze-free parties at coffee shops are gaining steam around the country. In predominantly white Seattle, these parties are also a space for Latino immigrants to connect with their roots.

item.title: Family lanes are popping up at airport security
item.description: There are new family friendly security lines popping up at airports around the country. It's a way to give people traveling with children extra time to get screened with less stress.

item.title: LA's booming gothicumbia scene mixes goth counterculture and traditional cumbia music
item.description: The booming gothicumbia scene mixes goth counterculture with traditional Latin American cumbia music â€” into a fun, bombastic mix of styles. Los Angeles is an incubator of this type of cultural trend.

item.title: Homeland Security Investigations raided a Georgia battery plant, detaining 475 people
item.description: The federal raid at a Hyundai and LG battery plant construction site in Georgia comes as the South Korean automaker has made significant efforts to manufacture cars and components in the U.S.
